title.narrative: IDLO Access to Justice - Inception Phase 2017
IDLO Access to Justice - Inception Phase 2017

description.narrative:
Ambassaden avser att under sex månader 2017 stödja IDLO:s uppstartsfas av programmet "Access to Justice". Det initiala stödet till IDLO under uppstartsfasen kommer att möjliggöra:
• att IDLO utvecklar ett slutligt programdokument • etablering av IDLO-kontor/närvaro i landet samt • planering och förberedelser för genomförande av ett långsiktigt "Access to Justice"-program
Uppstartsfasen kommer att inkludera följande aspekter/element; inrättande av organisation, budgetering, stärkt partnerskapsbyggande, framtagande av en lämplig förändringsteori samt av ett programdokument för långsiktigt stöd som innefattar tillgång till rättvisa, inklusive rättslig prövning och rättssäkerhet.
Den totala budgeten för uppstartfasen är 3 160 000 SEK. Uppstartfasen planeras pågå under sex månader från det att avtal skrivs under.

The overall goal of the Programme is to enhance access to justice for the most vulnerable and marginalised people living in rural areas, where accessibility of quality, affordable, fair justice services, or provision of legal assistance, remains challenging. The Programme seeks to legally-empower grassroots communities (with a specific focus on women, children and the marginalised), and enhance the capacity of duty bearers at the community level to provide the most vulnerable and disadvantaged citizens with quality legal knowledge and skills building to uphold their basic rights, challenge their grievances in an equitable manner, and obtain gender-sensitived justice remedy, and reparation or compensation.
The Inception phase will provide information and basis for supporting access to justice and rule of law that addresses challenges faced by the most vulnerable groups in Ugandan. It will provide IDLO with information on how best to design the programme that responds to the needs of the people.

description.narrative: The inception phase of IDLO's programme for Community Justice in Uganda was carried out during a bit more than a year. This was slightly longer than expected, but resulted in a comprehensive programme document for a full programme and reached the intended outcomes. To reach the intended results, a large number of consultations have been held to inform the programme formulation. While doing so, several stakeholders within both formal and informal justice systems have been trained and outreach activities have been held to increase awareness of citizens to claim their rights. IDLO has also developed internal control policies and improved grant monitoring and reporting mechanisms in accordance with needs in the Ugandan context. Hiring of staff and securing office space has also been necessary. The stakeholder consultations and participation of justice sector actor's in different international fora have been key activities during the inception phase, which have had a positive impact through development of action points in the programme document for the full programme design. Enhancement of gender equality analysis and mainstreaming has been a priority, which has resulted in a stronger programme design There have been a challenge to recruit key personnel, mainly due to the short inception phase and that no guarantees for a continuation could be given until the full programme agreement was signed. There has also been challenges in obtaining legal registration in Uganda even if a signing of the final agreement is expected early 2019. One lesson learnt from the inception phase is that there is a need to include state institutions under the Justice, Law and Order Sector in the work ahead to build capacity of duty bearers to deliver justice services, while supporting non-state actors to build capacities for the citizenry to demand for services. The initial idea was to focus only on non-state actors, but this has proved not to be a desired approach. IDLO recognises the challenge of possible mismanagement and abuse of resources. As a result of the inception phase, IDLO has made sure to strengthen program and financial management arrangements to ensure tighter monitoring. It has also been obvious that it is important to make it possible for justice actors to learn from peers, not the least from the region. This is a source of lessons learnt, good practices and valuable networks. The full programme will make this possible, maybe to a greater extent than intended at the outset. Overall, the inception period has provided IDLO with a good understanding of the operational context and the actors (both state and non-state actors) involved in justice service delivery in Uganda. As a result, IDLO was able to design a well informed programme taking into account existing approaches, gaps, challenges while developing possible mitigation strategies for identified risks.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
